'''Carolina Slim''' (August 22, 1923 – October 22, 1953)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1950.html |title=The 50s and earlier |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] guitarist and singer.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p16309/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Carolina Slim |author=Charlotte Dillon |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 28, 2010}}</ref> His best known tracks were "Black Cat Trail" and "I'll Never Walk in Your Door".<ref name="Dead"/> He used various pseudonyms during his relatively brief recording career, including '''Country Paul''', '''Jammin' Jim''', '''Lazy Slim Jim''' and '''Paul Howard'''.<ref name="Wirz">{{cite web |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/carosfrm.htm |title=Carolina Slim discography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref> In total he recorded 27 songs, but details of his life outside of his music career are scant, and the exact reasons concerning the usage of differing names are also unclear.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Carolina Slim was born '''Edward P. Hughes''' in [[Leasburg, North Carolina]], [[United States]]. He learned to play the guitar from his father, and was influenced by [[Lightnin' Hopkins]] and [[Blind Boy Fuller]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Negro">{{cite web |url=http://negroartist.com/writings/Carolina%20Slim%20%281923-1953%29.htm |title=Carolina Slim (1923-1953) |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Negroartist.com |accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref> He later found work as an itinerant musician around [[Durham, North Carolina]].<ref name="Toto">{{cite web |url=http://toto.lib.unca.edu/sounds/piedmontblues/carolina_slim.html |title=Carolina Slim |author=Landis Lacey |date=2003 |work= |publisher=Tot.lib.unca.edu |accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref>

In 1950, he relocated to [[Newark, New Jersey]], and made his recording debut for the [[Savoy Records|Savoy ]] [[record label|label]], billed as Carolina Slim.<ref name="AMG"/> His first [[Single (music)|single]] was "Black Chariot Blues" b/w "Mama's Boogie", recorded on July 24, 1950, and released on [[Acorn Records]] (Acorn 3015), a subsidiary of Savoy.<ref name="Wirz"/> In 1951 and 1952, he recorded eight tracks for the [[King Records (United States)|King]] label in [[New York City|New York]], this time using the name of Country Paul.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Tracey">{{cite book
| first= Steven C.
| last= Tracey
| year= 1993
| title= Going to Cincinnati: A History of the Blues in the Queen City
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Illinois Press 
| location= [[Champaign, Illinois]]
| isbn= 0-252-01999-7
| page= 140}}</ref> [[Henry Glover]] met Slim at these recordings, and later commented that Slim was "a very sickly young man at the time".<ref name="Tracey"/> Slim's style blended Piedmont blues, prominent in songs such as "Carolina Boogie" and his [[cover version]] of Fuller's "Rag Mama Rag", with the influence of Hopkins meaning that he increasingly veered towards [[Texas blues]].<ref name="Toto"/> Occasionally, Slim incorporated a [[washboard]] as well as his more regular guitar, as if to emphasise his Carolina rootstock.<ref name="Toto"/>

His recordings were not hugely popular, but sold in sufficient amounts for him to retain his [[recording contract]]. In June 1952, Slim recorded four more tracks for Savoy, but these were to be his final offerings.<ref name="Toto"/>

Carolina Slim died in Newark, New Jersey, from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] suffered whilst undergoing surgery for a back complaint. He was 30 years old.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1994, [[Document Records|Document]] released a [[compilation album]], ''Complete Recorded Works 1950-1952'', which incorporated all of his 27 tracks.<ref name="Album">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/complete-recorded-works-1950-1952-mw0000105965 |title=Complete Recorded Works 1950-1952 - Carolina Slim | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>
